hints.content:
The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is the number of equal parts being counted.

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is the number of equal parts in **one** whole. 

$\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{numerator}}}{\blueD{\text{denominator}}}$

The $\blueD{\text{denominator}}$ is $\blueD4$, so we need $\blueD4$ equal pieces in each whole.

The $\purpleD{\text{numerator}}$ is $\purpleD{8}$, so we need $\purpleD8$ equal parts shaded.

The following images show $\dfrac84$ shaded:


[[☃ image 1]]


[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: Two circles. Each circle is divided into 4 equal parts. Both circles have 4 parts that are shaded. !
Three circles. Each circle is divided into 4 equal parts. The first circle has 3 parts shaded. The second circle has 3 parts shaded. The third circle has 2 parts shaded !

question.content:
Each circle represents $1$ whole.

**Which images show $\dfrac8{4}$ shaded?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

choices.content: ![Two circles. Each circle is divided into 4 equal parts. Both circles have 4 parts that are shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3e33a9bdc9a86d9f4ff9391a40abac2d302adbd7)

![Three circles. Each circle is divided into 4 equal parts. The first circle has 3 parts shaded. The second circle has 2 parts shaded. The third circle has 4 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7d2e394a28ff7e352947600309cc2c619ea77c94)

![Three circles. Each circle is divided into 4 equal parts. The first circle has 3 parts shaded. The second circle has 3 parts shaded. The third circle has 2 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f6617d4aa8eeb7afefc2e29343d22a25405a960a)
![Two circles. Each circle is divided into 4 equal parts. Both circles have 2 parts shaded.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/4ee4fee22f941a0313ce13e9ba46ccc4e0fda7ea)
